generif.text: Results suggest that Orai1, -2, and -3 channels are similarly inhibited by extracellular calcium, indicating similar affinities for Ca(2+) within the selectivity filter.

Expression of a dominant-negative mutant Orai3, either alone or in cells expressing wild-type Orai1, profoundly and specifically reduces currents through the ARC channels without affecting those through the CRAC channels.
The effects of 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate on orai1, orai2, orai3 metabolism in HEK293 cells with and without STIM1 are reported.
analysis of store-dependent and -independent modes regulating Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ channel activity of human Orai1 and Orai3

stimulation of Orai3 currents by 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate occurred along with an alteration of the permeation pathway that represents a unique mechanism for regulating ion channel selectivity by chemical compounds
analysis of activation of Orai1-3 channels by a STIM1 coiled-coil mutant

Data show that the fast Ca(2+)-dependent inactivation is mediated by three conserved glutamates in the C termini (CT) of Orai2 and Orai3, which show prominent fast Ca(2+)-dependent inactivation compared with Orai1.
Heteromeric Orai1/3 protein assembly provides a concept for less Ca(2+)-selective store-operated channels.
differential redox sensitivity of ORAI1 and ORAI3 channels depends mainly on an extracellularly located reactive cysteine, which is absent in ORAI3
there is a selective requirement for Orai3 versus Orai1 in estrogen receptor-positive versus estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer cells
With these data we show a new Ca(2)(+) entry pathway linked to the Ca(2)(+)/inositolphosphate second-messenger system in RPE cells which help to further understand regulatory pathways of agonists.

Results provide strong evidence for a significant effect of Orai3 on breast cancer cell growth in vitro and show that this effect is associated with the induction of cell cycle and apoptosis resistance.
the N-terminal conserved region plays a multifaceted role in Orai3 current gating with distinct structural requirements for STIM1- and 2-APB-stimulated activation.
data establish Orai3 as an ERalpha-regulated channel and a potential selective therapeutic target for ERalpha(+) breast cancers
High ORAI3 expression is associated with breast cancer.
Orai3 constitutes a native store-operated calcium entry pathway in non small cell lung adenocarcinoma that controls cell proliferation and cell cycle progression, likely via Akt pathway.
Orai1 and Orai3 proteins are more important than calcium influx to control cell proliferation.

The higher amplitude of store-operated Ca2+ entry was associated to the over-expression for Stim2, Orai2-3, and TRPC1 while Stim2 levels remained constant and Stim1, Orai1, Orai3, TRPC1 and TRPC4 proteins were over-expressed in primary myelofibrosis.

A channel chimera of Orai3 with the N terminus of Orai1 was able to couple local Ca(2+) entry to NFAT activation, identifying the N-terminal domain of Orai1 as central to Ca(2+) nanodomain-transcription coupling.
Suggest disrupted dynamic equilibrium of channel-forming ORAI proteins as an oncogenic mechanism in prostate cancer.
Orai3 down-tunes efficient STIM1 gating when in a heteromeric complex with Orai1.

Overall high Orai3/Orai1 ratios in human prostate epithelial cells and androgen-insensitive cancer cells contribute to their ROS resistance and thereby may have a share in making the prostate one of the most prominent cancer susceptible organs
results identified the ORAI-NOX2 feedback loop as a determinant of monocyte immune responses.

mRNA expression in differentiated keratinocytes increased with increasing age of donors, and the increase corresponded well to slower recovery of [Ca2+]i from hydraulic stress-induced elevation in keratinocytes of older donors

These data suggest that Orai3 channel does not participate in the thapsigargin-revealed ER Ca(2+) leak but forms an ER Ca(2+) leak channel that is limiting the overloading with Ca(2+) of the ER store.
ORAI1-3, are preferentially expressed in proximal tubular epithelial cells and downregulated in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

discovered that it was not the N termini, but the loop2 regions connecting TM2 and TM3 of Orai1 and Orai3 that featured distinct properties, which explained the different, isoform-specific behavior of Orai N-truncation mutants.
the conserved portion of the Orai N terminus is essential for STIM1, as it fine-tunes the open Orai channel gating, thereby establishing authentic CRAC channel activity.

Resistance was dependent on external calcium presence and thus Orai3 functionality. This effect allowed a downregulation of the p53 tumor suppressor protein expression via the pro-survival PI3K/Sgk-1/Sek-1 pathway. We demonstrated that p53 degradation occurred not only via Mdm2, but also via another unexpected E3 ubiquitin ligase, Nedd4-2.
miR18a and miR18b positively regulate Orai3 whereas miR34a represses Orai3 expression and function.

The differential expression of 55 genes involved in Ca(2+) signaling highlighted that only ORAI3 expression was significantly altered in smokers (regardless of COPD status). ORAI3 is involved in epithelial cell calcium signaling. ORAI3 is additionally involved in ciliary beating.
Distinct pharmacological profiles of ORAI1, ORAI2, and ORAI3 channels.
ORAI3 silencing alters cell proliferation and promotes mitotic catastrophe and apoptosis in pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
High ORAI3 expression correlates with good prognosis in human muscle-invasive bladder cancer.
Role of Orai3 in the Pathophysiology of Cancer.
Orai3 Calcium Channel Regulates Breast Cancer Cell Migration through Calcium-Dependent and -Independent Mechanisms.
Orai3 Calcium Channel Contributes to Oral/Oropharyngeal Cancer Stemness through the Elevation of ID1 Expression.

name: ORAI calcium release-activated calcium modulator 3
summary: Predicted to enable store-operated calcium channel activity. Predicted to be involved in store-operated calcium entry. Predicted to be located in plasma membrane. Predicted to be integral component of membrane. Predicted to be active in membrane. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
